sentence.text: This Egyptian 5-year-old boy (III.1) was the first child to this family.
A younger sister (Patient 2) was similarly affected (Fig. 1), and another younger brother was healthy.
He was born at term after an uneventful pregnancy.
His birth weight is reported as low but was not recorded.
His motor development was delayed (he was walking at 2.5-year old).
His language development was significantly retarded and hearing test at the age of 3 showed moderate sensorineural hearing loss.
On examination at that age, his weight, height, and head circumference were 15 kg (−1.6 SD), 97.2 cm (−2.4 SD), and 51.3 cm (mean), respectively.
Upper/lower segment ratio was 1.5 and arm span was 89 cm.

The boy (Fig. 2) had small short nose with upturned nostrils, hypertelorism, midface hypoplasia, long philtrum, bow-shaped mouth, high arched palate, relatively small ears, hypoplastic nipples, and abnormal wide ends of long bones.
In addition, the clinical features included a prominent occiput, mild parietal and frontal bossing, mild generalized brachydactyly, and bilateral clinodactyly of the little fingers.
Because of the sensorineural deafness, he is wearing a hearing aid.
Non-verbal IQ test was 76.
Ophthalmologic evaluation (using indirect ophthalmoscope and slit lamp) showed normal lens, vitreous and fundus and normal visual acuity.
No abnormalities were found during the routine laboratory investigations (complete blood picture, thyroid hormone profile).
Metabolic screening and chromosomal examination from peripheral blood lymphocytes were normal.
Skeletal radiographs (Fig. 3) demonstrated short long bones (humerus, radius, ulna, femur, tibia, and fibula).
All had large epiphyses and flared metaphyses.
Carpal bones were large and the phalanges and metacarpals were short.
These features were associated with platyspondyly and coronal clefting.
Atlanto-axial and occipital bones showed no abnormalities.
Radiograph of pelvis and hips showed short and broad basilar portions of the ilia and relatively horizontal acetabular roofs, as well as coxa vara were seen.
There was no history of osteoarthritis until now.
